docs.abstract: The things that are driving us apart are going to keep driving us apart.
docs.snippet: The things that are driving us apart are going to keep driving us apart.
docs.lead_paragraph: There has been a remarkable erosion in public tolerance of “offensive expression about race, gender and religion,” according to a paper Dennis Chong and Morris Levy, political scientists at the University of Southern California, and Jack Citrin, a political scientist at Berkeley, presented in September at the annual meeting of the American Political Science Association.

headline.main: The Moral Chasm That Has Opened Up Between Left and Right Is Widening

docs.abstract: A robust body of research shows the benefits of integration. Why, then, is it so hard to achieve?
docs.snippet: A robust body of research shows the benefits of integration. Why, then, is it so hard to achieve?
docs.lead_paragraph: New York City, one of the most demographically diverse places on the planet, is also home to one of the most segregated school districts in America. That contrast has rattled New York’s self-image and given rise to major integration efforts over the past several years. Most have failed. And across America, desegregation has never been tried at scale, partly because of resistance from white liberals.

headline.main: How White Progressives Undermine School Integration

docs.abstract: Why do some mass gatherings turn violent? Experts in crowd behavior say there’s still much to learn.
docs.snippet: Why do some mass gatherings turn violent? Experts in crowd behavior say there’s still much to learn.
docs.lead_paragraph: The reign of King Louis Philippe, the last king of France, came to an abrupt and ignominious end on Feb. 24, 1848, after days of increasingly violent demonstrations in Paris and months of mounting agitation with the government’s policies.

headline.print_headline: A Theory of Chaos: Analyzing Crowd Behavior

docs.abstract: On Juneteenth, a holiday that honors the end of slavery in America, the vice president said that “all lives matter’’ but twice declined to say that black lives matter.
docs.snippet: On Juneteenth, a holiday that honors the end of slavery in America, the vice president said that “all lives matter’’ but twice declined to say that black lives matter.
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Vice President Mike Pence twice refused to say that “black lives matter” during an interview on a Philadelphia television station on Friday, insisting instead that “all lives matter in a very real sense.”

headline.main: Pence Won’t Say the Words ‘Black Lives Matter’ in an Interview
headline.print_headline: Pence Won’t Say ‘Black Lives Matter’ in a Juneteenth Interview

docs.abstract: Both men had similar backgrounds, working for years as Secret Service agents but considered more skilled in navigating the agency’s political infighting than as experts in protection. Both went on to land plum assignments: the sergeants-at-arms of the Senate and House.
docs.lead_paragraph: Both men had similar backgrounds, working for years as Secret Service agents but considered more skilled in navigating the agency’s political infighting than as experts in protection. Both went on to land plum assignments: the sergeants-at-arms of the Senate and House.

headline.main: Sergeants-at-arms face questions about a failure to do more to protect Congress.

byline.original: By Michael S. Schmidt and Ali Watkins

docs.abstract: More than 200 said they stood in solidarity with three former co-workers who have accused the company of discrimination.
docs.snippet: More than 200 said they stood in solidarity with three former co-workers who have accused the company of discrimination.
docs.lead_paragraph: The messages used words like disappointed, disheartened, angered, upset, ashamed, frustrated, infuriated, disillusioned, deeply saddened and disturbed. On Friday, 236 employees of Pinterest, a company known for its virtual pinboards, expressed solidarity on an internal chat app with three former co-workers who have accused the company of racial and sex discrimination and retaliation.

headline.main: Pinterest Employees Demand Gender and Race Equality
headline.print_headline: Employees At Pinterest Take Actions For Equality

docs.abstract: Coinbase, Expensify, Soylent, Clubhouse and others are embroiled in a culture war over politics and the workplace.
docs.snippet: Coinbase, Expensify, Soylent, Clubhouse and others are embroiled in a culture war over politics and the workplace.
docs.lead_paragraph: Rob Rhinehart, a co-founder of nutritional drink start-up Soylent, declared in a blog post last week that he was supporting Kanye West for president.

headline.main: To Do Politics or Not Do Politics? Tech Start-Ups Are Divided
headline.print_headline: Tech Start-Ups Are Divided on Politics

byline.original: By Erin Griffith and Nathaniel Popper

docs.abstract: George Gascón is facing an intense backlash for enacting the sorts of policies demanded by protesters after the killing of George Floyd.
docs.snippet: George Gascón is facing an intense backlash for enacting the sorts of policies demanded by protesters after the killing of George Floyd.
docs.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — From inside the walls of Folsom State Prison, the two inmates, one a convicted murderer, clinked their cups of prison moonshine in a toast to the new district attorney of Los Angeles, George Gascón.

headline.main: Los Angeles Just Elected a Liberal D.A. He’s Already Facing a Recall Effort.
headline.print_headline: D.A. on the Left In Los Angeles Faces a Revolt

docs.abstract: It’s on us to become more discerning.
docs.snippet: It’s on us to become more discerning.
docs.lead_paragraph: Over the past five or so years, “disinformation” has become a catchall explanation for what ails the country. Everything from QAnon conspiracies to your aunt’s vaccine-hesitant Facebook confessions to Twitter bots that try to stir up online fights and deepen the country’s ideological divides are gathered under that label.

headline.main: Can We Get Smarter About Disinformation?

docs.abstract: It increasingly resembles a Washington version of the Green Zone that sheltered American and Iraqi officials in Baghdad.
docs.snippet: It increasingly resembles a Washington version of the Green Zone that sheltered American and Iraqi officials in Baghdad.
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump was furious when news got out last weekend that as protesters gathered outside the White House he had been rushed to an underground bunker. But now, as crowds keep coming back to demonstrate, the entire White House seems to be turning into one.

headline.main: Security Concerns Give the White House a Fortified New Look
headline.print_headline: The People’s House Is Now an Embattled President’s Fortress

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: United States Defense and Military Forces
